H0.text: Nucleus is the cellular organelle in which pyruvate (C3H4O3) is converted into carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O) during a biochemical reaction.

H1.text: Cytoplasm is the cellular organelle where pyruvate (C3H4O3) is converted into carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O) during the biochemical reaction.

H2.text: Mitochondria are the cellular organelles where pyruvate (C3H4O3) is converted into carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O) during a biochemical reaction.

H3.text: Endoplasmic reticulum is the cellular organelle where pyruvate (C3H4O3) is converted into carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O) during this biochemical reaction.

A4.text: The pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) is located in the mitochondria of eukaryotic cells and in the cytosol of prokaryotes.

A5.text: In the presence of oxygen, acetyl-CoA enters the citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle) inside the mitochondrial matrix, and is oxidized to CO2 while at the same time reducing NAD to NADH.
